notesStmt.note: BBWW performed in Boston, Mass., from June 10-22, 1895. Horace C. Alger (1857-1906) was a banker from Sheridan, Wyoming; he was mayor of Sheridan in 1889 and a candidate for Governor of Wyoming in 1898. Cody, Beck, and Alger were responsible for developing the Shoshone Irrigation Company. W. A. Paxton (1837-1907) was one of Omaha's leading entrepreneurs involved in cattle, stockyards, wholesale groceries, land, and politics. The Paxton-Gallagher business became renowned for its line of wholesale groceries, including Butternut coffee. The Paxton & Gallagher Wholesale Grocery Company was founded in 1879 by William Paxton and Benjamin Gallagher. Paxton was being pursued as a potential investor in The Shoshone Irrigation Company but later decided against investing [See Bonner, pp18, 31]. William E. Hymer (~1853-1933) was one of the early members of the Shoshone Land and Irrigation Company.

div1.p: Yours of the 11th to hand. And it cheered me up For from Mr Paxtons letter I took it for granted they were out of the deal entirely. But am glad they are not. We can put the 28000 acre tract through lay off Town. &c— and make money out of it.2 And it will be the starter for the others if we wish to go on with them Alger And I were getting up a Boston party to go out— And go into it.3 But if the Paxton party stays we wontwon't need them wire me quick. Do as you think best about Hymer— only letslet's carry it out—

back.note: Note 1: Buffalo Bill's Wild West performed daily (except Sunday) in Boston from June 10 through June 22, 1895.

Note 2: Cody and Beck were hoping to persuade Omaha businessman William A. Paxton to join their planned irrigation venture, which would eventually result in the construction of the Cody Canal and the founding of the town of Cody, Wyoming. Ultimately, Paxton decided not to invest in the Cody Canal.

Note 3: Cody refers to Horace C. Alger, who was George Beck's original partner in the venture that eventually became the Shoshone Irrigation Company. As a Harvard alumnus and a native of Massachusetts, Alger was an obvious choice to assist Cody in seeking investors in New England.
